review: This is a perfect solution for me. I love watching youtube and hbo go on my TV and this is exactly what the chromecast is designed for.I used to stream from my xbox but it constantly had to stop and buffer and seemed very laggy, despite having good internet service. But now I can do all the same things, controlling it with my phone or ipad without all the frustration I had before. It takes only a few minutes to set up but once you get through that it feels very seemless. I was worried that there would be compatibility issues with my apple devices (which wouldn't have surprised me, those corporate ******) but I'm happy to say they all work together nicely.There are more options out there but for the money this is the best option for me. I'm usually hard-to-please and persnickety when it comes to electronics so this is saying a lot.Perfect gift for anyone with a TV and a smartphone and/or tablet.

author: Krisstyro

review: I find it rather annoying that people will give this 1 star because, for example, Chromecast does not support Amazon Instant Video yet.Seriously? Did it claim to support Amazon Instant Video when you bought it?? There are many critical and unfair reviews for this product, in my opinion.What you get is a product that can (and will in time) stream media that is currently being viewed on your mobile device or Chrome Browser and allow that media to be played through your TV by casting it to your Chromecast. Plain and simple.Setup went fine.When using supported apps such as Netflix, Pandora, and Google Music, it worked seamlessly and flawlessly. The media arrived on my TV screen within ample time and the quality was excellent. The tab-casting is a little slow, but works. Streaming media off of your computer with the RealPlayer cloud was a good solution, but would not stream full HD 1080 videos from my computer, sadly.In between streams, the Chromecast has a lovely idle screen with scenic views and the current time displaying.You are also buying an ever-evolving product which will have more compatibility with more services in the future.In all, for $25-$35 you are getting a device that is capable of what most $50-$100 similar devices do. It is a little limited in that it does not have the 100's of worthless 'channels' provided by Roku, but It's worth skipping the silly Roku controller and using your smartphone or tablet as the controller. Roku has an app for this, apparently, but Chromecast gives you the flexibility of controlling and browsing for what you want while in the Native app environment in the app created by the content provider.And...It's only about $30.When you consider the price-point AND YOU UNDERSTAND WHAT THE DEVICE DOES AND DOES NOT DO WHEN YOU BUY IT, it's a great product.
